content:
Hi,

I'm trying to use open ... to override a name imported from Mathlib with a locally defined data constructor, but type inference fails to pick it up. Here is my minified code:

import Mathlib

inductive Term where
  | Zero

open Term

-- This works
#check Zero

/-
overloaded, errors
  9:8 ambiguous, possible interpretations
    _root_.Zero : Type ?u.202 → Type ?u.202

    Term.Zero : Term

  invalid {...} notation, expected type is not known
-/
#check {Zero}

/-
ambiguous, possible interpretations
  _root_.Zero : Type ?u.207 → Type ?u.207

  Term.Zero : Term
-/
#check id Zero

How do I hide _root_.Zero, or even better, not import it at all? Currently the only work-around I can think of is to rename the data constructor :sad: I've search the whole zulip and found nothing related to this issue. Is anyone else experiencing similar problems?
You can put your code in a namespace. That being said, this is a huge quibble I have with mathlib, that the library controls how users use the same names that it does. This is bad library design.

@Shreyas Srinivas Good idea! How did I not think of that :thinking:

However, everything I try with namespaces results in the same problem. I tried wrapping everything except import Mathlib in a namespace and also everything except the import and inductive definition to no avail...
that's because Zero inside your namespace is further namespaced as Term.Zero
For a moment there I thought you had already added open Term Never mind. I'll paste the working example
you'd hope that something like open _root_ () would work...
but unfortunately it doesn't
My bad, I just ended up adding Term.Zero. This is indeed a very annoying aspect of Mathlib.
No worries @Shreyas Srinivas , thanks for taking a look :)

Edward van de Meent said:

you'd hope that something like open _root_ () would work...

That would be nice. But given that it doesn't exist, the responsible course of action is for Mathlib to be namespaced, which doesn't seem to be happening.
i guess we basically want external modules automatically get namespaced? or maybe an option in the lakefile to make certain modules namespaced?
Namespacing by default would be nice.
But qualified imports would be better

Shreyas Srinivas said:

But given that it doesn't exist, the responsible course of action is for Mathlib to be namespaced, which doesn't seem to be happening.

I think there's a good chance this would happen if someone stepped up to champion it and do the work
I tried it. I put Mathlib's Vector in a Mathlib namespace. Later PRs removed it
I am not sure there is widespread agreement about it based on the last mathlib community meeting I attended.

i guess it makes sense that internally you dont want to have to deal with the hassle of opening Mathlib every time you create a new file...
also, i believe the point of getting Vector into a namespace was to prevent collision with core/batteries' version, not "put all mathlib things into a mathlib namespace just in case"?

1. I think a little namespacing discipline should not be treated as a hassle, but as a good habit to be acquired.
  2. Yes, but it was an opportunity to initiate the process.

Also, based on discord discussions I recall that adding qualified imports will mess up the way name resolution and tactics work without making changes to the way Lean.Names are resolved. So clearly Mathlib getting namespaced is the better option.

I can't see how it gets simpler. If someone is really importing all of Mathlib, then they'll likely do open Mathlib or a variant with a long list of hiding or inclusion. In this particular case, doing a naked #check is not the most common behavior. In more likelihood, elaboration can discern which identifier is being referenced. And if one wants to refer to the Term, one can also use .Zero in situations where the type is inferred as Term.

What about Nat? That doesn't come from Mathlib. There would often be churn about what is namespaced as Mathlib and what isn't (as things move across libraries). Either downstream users have to clean up their explicit namespacing, or they do open Mathlib etc at the top of their files and we're back to where we started
"Most common behavior"? Those checks might not be in the final output but everyone is bound to have a different style when building the files.
As for Nat, I recall that it comes from Prelude and can be excluded with the prelude keyword
.Zero doesn't work on #check in the above example

@Yakov Pechersky I already get quite confused with what stuff comes from Mathlib and what is in vanilla Lean... I wouldn't mind doing open Mathlib (...) if I can control what I bring to the namespace because pin-pointing imports makes the code more clear. Also, things moving across libraries and changing paths is considered backward incompatible in my opinion.
Ideally there should be way to hide names with open <namespace>

Shreyas Srinivas said:

As for Nat, I recall that it comes from Prelude and can be excluded with the prelude keyword

using the prelude keyword does seem like a very overkill solution to this issue, imo...
You are right. But more importantly, even if such a feature to hide names when opening a namespace existed, it would only be useful if Mathlib were namespaced

Sorry to contribute only obvious information but:

  • Zero is not part of Mathlib
  • If you don’t like Mathlib and are annoyed with it, a pretty straightforward fix is to not use it.
Niklas, what do you expect #check {Zero} to mean?
The type of bracket does not seem to matter for that error message

Whoops, you are right! Now id Zero type checks but {Zero} does not. I expected it to be a singleton Set, which is a concept from Mathlib. So the question now is how to get singleton set notation to work with my Zero data constructor.
Give Term an instance of Singleton
docs#Singleton

Sorry, I meant the singleton for Set: I need ({Zero} : Set Term) in my actual project.

To clarify: I need Sets from mathlib in a way that Init.Prelude.Zero doesn't cause namespace issues with my Term.Zero.
Edit: Mathlib.Init.Zero is from an old version.
There is already an instance for singleton sets : https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Defs.html#Set.instSingletonSet
You should be able to use it as is
With a qualified name like Term.Zero

Yes it works with Term.Zero but not with Zero when I have opened Term before it. See this example:

import Mathlib.Data.Set.Defs

namespace Stuff

inductive Term where
  | Zero

#check Zero -- Init.Prelude
open Term

-- This works
#check Zero -- Stuff.Term.Zero

/-
overloaded, errors
  23:9 ambiguous, possible interpretations
    _root_.Zero : Type ?u.129 → Type ?u.129

    Term.Zero : Term

  invalid {...} notation, expected type is not of the form (C ...)
    Set Term
-/
#check ({Zero} : Set Term)
#check Zero

/-
ambiguous, possible interpretations
  _root_.Zero : Type ?u.134 → Type ?u.134

  Term.Zero : Term
-/
#check id Zero

end Stuff

lean web
Yeah so that's a name clash. Nothing to do with Set notation.

Watch out, #check Zero and #check (Zero) are different. The first does signature pretty printing and doesn't elaborate Zero, but the second does. I'm not sure why the name resolution rules are different — that seems like a bug in #check to me.

Thanks to @Shreyas Srinivas's suggestion to use abbrev (and namespace) I managed to resolve the name conflict.
Here is my final code:

import Mathlib.Tactic

namespace Stuff

inductive Term where
  | Zero
  | Succ : Term → Term

-- This is the Zero from Init.Prelude
#check Zero
#check (Zero)

open Term

#check Zero -- Works
#check (Zero) -- Ambiguous
#check ({Zero} : Set Term) -- Ambiguous

abbrev Zero := Term.Zero
abbrev Succ := Term.Succ

-- All of the following work now!
#check Zero
#check (Zero)
#eval Succ Zero

#check ({Zero} : Set Term)
#check Zero

end Stuff

After adding abbrev Zero := Term.Zero Lean doesn't complain about ambuity anymore.
Hopefully this is useful to everyone dealing with the same issue :big_smile:
Niklas Halonen has marked this topic as resolved.
